conclusion: Determine the maximum value of the horizontal force F such that blocks A and B remain relatively stationary.
Block A is on top of block B. A horizontal force F is applied to block B.
The mass of block A is 1kg and that of block B is 2kg. The maximum static friction force between A and B is 1 N. The coefficient of kinetic friction between B and the ground is 0.1. g = 10 m/s².

premise: Weight of block A: W_A = m_A g = 1 kg × 10 m/s² = 10 N
conclusion: Normal force from block B on A: N_{BA} = W_A = 10 N

premise: Maximum static friction force between A and B: f_{s\max} = 1 N
conclusion: For block A to remain stationary relative to block B, the static friction force must be sufficient to provide the necessary acceleration.

premise: Net force on block A in the horizontal direction: f_s = m_A a
conclusion: f_s ≤ 1 N, m_A a ≤ 1 N, 1 kg × a ≤ 1 N, a ≤ 1 m/s²

premise: Weight of block B: W_B = m_B g = 2 kg × 10 m/s² = 20 N
conclusion: Total weight of A and B: W_{AB} = W_A + W_B = 10 N + 20 N = 30 N

premise: Total weight of A and B: W_{AB} = 30 N
conclusion: Normal force from the ground on B: N_{ground} = W_{AB} = 30 N

premise: Normal force from the ground on B: N_{ground} = 30 N
conclusion: Kinetic friction force between B and the ground: f_k = μ_k N_{ground} = 0.1 × 30 N = 3 N

premise: Net force on block B in the horizontal direction: F - f_k = m_B a
From the analysis of block A, a ≤ 1 m/s²
conclusion: Substitute a = 1 m/s² into the equation for block B: F - 3 N = 2 kg × 1 m/s²
